documents.title: Memorandum and Order
documents.text:
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
EASTERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK
-------------------------------X
  MEMORANDUM AND ORDER
    99-CV-2844(DRH) 
In re NASSAU COUNTY STRIP              
SEARCH CASES
     
-------------------------------X
A P P E A R A N C E S:
For Plaintiffs:
Herbst Law PLLC
420 Lexington Avenue - Suite 300
New York, New York 10170
       By: Robert L. Herbst, Esq.
Giskan Solotaroff Anderson & Stewart LLP
11 Broadway Suite 2150
New York, New York 10004
  By: Iliana Konidaris, Esq.
Beldock Levine & Hoffman LLP
99 Park Avenue, Suite 1600
New York, New York 10016
  By: Jonathan C. Moore, Esq.
 
Emery Celli Brinckerhoff & Abady LLP
75 Rockefeller Plaza, 20th Floor
New York, New York 10019
  By: Matthew D. Brinckerhoff, Esq.
Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz, LLP
270 Madison Avenue
New York, New York 10016
  By: Jeffrey G. Smith, Esq.
For Defendants:
Nassau County Attorney's Office 
Carnell T. Foskey
Acting County Attorney
One West Street
Mineola, New York 11501
  By:  Liora M. Ben-Sorek, Esq.
HURLEY, Senior District Judge

In keeping with the Court's request at the January 29,
2014 status conference, plaintiffs' counsel, under covering
letter dated February 23, 2014, submitted a "proposed Final
Judgment, with the Notices and Claim Forms as exhibits, for [my],
review."  (Pls.' Feb. 23, 2014 Letter at 1.)  The County has
objected to, or suggested alternate language as to certain
portions of those submissions.  (See Defs.' Mar. 5, 2014 Letter.)
The purpose of this opinion is to address defendants'
comments about the proposed judgment and the accompanying notice
and claim forms. 
Defendants' Comments as to Certain Core Facts 
and the Procedural History of the Case as set 
          Forth in the Proposed Judgment               
The first two pages of the proposed judgment provide a
fairly detailed recitation of the case's procedural history along
with some facts (e.g. number of strip searches) and conclusions
(e.g. reasons defendants conceded liability).  Defendants have
expressed concerns about what is included, as well as what is
absent from the introductory language, thereby bringing to the
fore the issue of whether anything beyond a brief preface to the
judgment's decretal paragraphs is required or, indeed, desirable.
Given the history and purpose of the separate document
rule under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 58(a), the answer to
both of the above questions is "no."  As Judge Easterbrook
writing for a panel of the Seventh Circuit succinctly noted in
-2-

Citizens Elec. Corp. v. Bituminous Fire & Marine Ins. Co: "Like
any proper judgment, the decree entered in this case . . . . says
who is liable for how much, then stops."  68 F.3d 1016, 1021 (7th
Cir. 1995); see also In re Cendant Corp. Securities Litigation,
454 F.3d 235, 243 (3d Cir. 2006)("Our conclusion that the
separate-document requirement does not allow for an extended
presentation of facts and procedural history is supported by
Model Forms 31 and 321 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure
('Judgment on Jury Verdict' and 'Judgment on Decision by the
Court').  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 58 advisory committee notes on 2002
amendments.")  This is not to say that plaintiffs violated the
separate document rule under Second Circuit law via their
submission or that prefatory recitation provided was inaccurate. 
I do not believe either to be the case.  But based on its
problematic character, the dispute between the parties as to its
contents will not be further discussed.  Rather, the first two
pages of the proposed judgment have been replaced by the Court
with a single introductory sentence consistent with the purpose
of Rule 58 and the sentiment expressed by Judge Easterbrook in
the In re Cendant Corp. Securities Litigation.  
Defendants' Objection to the Suggested Post-
          Judgment Interest Rate in the Proposed Judgment
1  Forms 31 and 32 have been renumbered and re-titled such
that currently, Form 70 is "Judgment on a Verdict" and Form 71 is
"Judgement by the Court Without a Jury."
-3-

Plaintiffs have included the New York post-judgment
rate of 9% in the proposed judgment.  Defendants contend that the
federal interest rate set forth in 28 U.S.C. ยง 1961 applies. 
Neither party provides authority for their position beyond
identifying the statutory provision believed to be controlling. 
Nonetheless, a fair reading of Section 1961 viewed in conjunction
with established case law indicating that the Section applies to
diversity cases, support defendants' position.  Cf. Schipani v.
McLeod, 541 F.3d 158, 164 (2d Cir. 2008)("In a diversity case . .
. . post judgment interest is governed by federal statute [, viz.
28 U.S.C. ยง 1961(a)]" and Plaut v. Estate of Rogers, 959 F. Supp.
1302, 1309 (D.C. Colo,. 1997)("[T]he appropriate post-judgment
interest rate in all cases in federal court, including diversity
cases, is governed by federal law.  The applicable rate is set
forth in 28 U.S.C. ยง 1961, entitled 'Interest.'").  Accordingly,
the proposed judgment has been modified by providing for post-
judgment being assessed at the federal, not the state rate.
Defendants' Objection to Provision in the
          Proposed Judgment Ordering Payment of the 
Amount of the Judgment Into Court                   
Plaintiffs' proposed judgment directs defendants "to
deposit into Court the sum of $11,508,000 within 30 days of entry
of final judgment."  (Proposed Judgment at 4.)  That provision
should be stricken, defendants argue, because it is unnecessary
given the financial status of the County, as well as supposedly
-4-

irreconcilable with my earlier statement that no bond would be
required to secure a stay of judgment should a stay ultimately be
granted by this Court.  (See Sept. 20, 2013 Tr. at 14, and Oct.
18, 2013 Tr. at 21:20-21.)  
Plaintiffs counter by observing that "[t]here is a
significant difference between not posting a bond for purposes of
appeal and the provision of the final judgment requiring the
deposit of the judgment amount into Court.  What the County will
do after judgment is entered is a separate matter that has no
bearing on the issue."  (Pls. Mar. 7, 2014 Letter at 2.)  The
precise nature of that distinction as a practical matter may be
elusive for in each instance defendants are required to provide
something of value โ either a bond or cash โ to assure that
adequate funds will be on hand at the end of the appeals process
should plaintiffs continue to prevail.  Nonetheless, appealing a
judgment with a concomitant request for a stay implicates a
different stage of the proceeding than the entry of the judgment
itself.  
When and if a stay of judgment is sought, the subject
of the present dispute will become germane but not before.  And,
based on Nassau County's well-publicized financial challenges as
of late, depositing the sums awarded for attorney's fees and
expenses with the Clerk of Court is appropriate and is thus
directed pursuant to the judgment which the Court has signed
-5-

today.
Continued Payment of Administrative Costs by County  
Defendants, in their March 5, 2014 letter, correctly
note that "[t]o date, the Court has imposed administrative fees
(such as copying and mailing of notices by the Class
Administrator) upon the Defendants."  (Defs.' Mar. 5, 2014 Letter
at 3.)  That practice, defendants maintain, should now be changed
because (1) "[s]hould the County prevail upon appeal of the Final
Judgment, it will not be able to recoup those expenditures," and
(2) "[b]ecause CPLR ยง 904(d) permits the Court to direct a
plaintiff to bear the costs of class notices, and in light of the
change in law (at least the Federal law) with regard to
permissibility of strip searches upon admission to correctional
centers, the Defendants' [sic] respectfully request that this
Court revisit its prior order and shift the future administration
expenses to the plaintiffs."  Id.
In response, plaintiffs argue "CPLR ยง 904(d) is not
applicable to this federal case, and even if arguendo it were, it
would not require imposing the costs upon plaintiffs.  The fact
that the federal claims were dismissed is no reason to shift the
costs of administration to plaintiffs in light of their having
prevailed, upon the County's concession of liability 10 years
ago, on the state constitutional claim."  (Pls.' Mar. 7, 2014
Reply at 2.)  
-6-

Plaintiffs' assertion as to the supposed
inapplicability of CPLR ยง 904(d) is presented as a supposed
truism.  However, since the soundness of that conclusion is not
obvious to the Court, and in view of the absence of supporting
authority being provided, I have assumed, arguendo, that ยง 904 is
germane.
Section 904(d)(I) provides that a court may, "if
justice requires," shift the cost of notification from the
plaintiff with whom the onus would typically rest to the
defendant in whole or in part.  CPLR ยง 901(d)(I).  Although
relevant case law is sparse, Pludeman v. Northern Leasing
Systems, Inc. instructs that the subject section authorizes
placing the notification costs with a defendant depending on "the
merits of the action, the defenses thereto, and the resources of
the respective parties."  74 A.D.3d 420, 425, 904 N.Y.S.2d 372,
378 (First Dep't 2010).  
Proceeding in reverse order, the County, even in its
diminished financial state, is presumably better able than
plaintiffs โ whose only link is the shared misfortune of having
been arrested for a non-felony offense and then undergoing the
humiliation of being strip searched upon entry to NCCC โ to
shoulder the costs of notification.  
As far as "the defense[]" to plaintiffs' claims is
concerned, defendants conceded liability, i.e. that their actions
-7-

did, in fact, violate each class member's constitutional right to
be secure in his or her person.  Basically what remains at this
juncture is for class members to respond to the general damages
notice by filing a claim and, for those who intend to pursue
special damages, to commence a new action for that purpose.  But,
of course, the landscape has changed since defendants' admission
of liability as a result of Florence and the dismissal of the
federal constitutional claim.  Still, the proposition that
Florence will serve as the vehicle (1) to erase their concession
of liability, and (2) for the New York Court of Appeals then โ
unencumbered by the concession โ to reconcile the subject strip
searches with the protections afforded to New York citizens under
Article I, Section 12 of New York State Constitution, is
problematic at best.  So yes, the County's prospects as far as
mounting a defense are arguably better than pre-Florence, but not
sufficiently better to shift the costs of notification from the
County to the class.
And as to the initial factor in Pludemane, viz. the
merits of the action, the observations just made about the
strength of defendants' defense to their admitted liability also
sheds light on the strength of plaintiffs' remaining claim viewed
as of this stage of the proceeding.  
In sum, defendants' arguments calling for the shift of
the notification costs from the defendants to plaintiffs are not
-8-

convincing.  
This concludes the Court's explanation to counsel
concerning the changes made to the draft judgment submitted by
plaintiffs.2  Attention will now be focused on the accompanying
proposed notice and claim forms.  In that regard, the sequence in
which the forms are discussed by the Court follows the order in
which they are addressed in the County's March 5th letter rather
than by their respective exhibit numbers as recited in the
judgment.  
Proposed Non-Book and Bail Draft Notice (Exhibit 3)
The word "them" has been deleted from the beginning of
the third line in the "Summary" portion of the Notice on the
first page as requested by defendants.  However, defendants'
objection to the third bullet point which they categorize as
providing "legal advice" is found to be without merit.  Class
members are entitled to be notified not only of the general
damages award but also of the other major benefit received by
class counsels on their behalf, i.e. the concession of liability
and the anticipated effect of that concession on subsequently
commenced lawsuits seeking special damages.
The misspelled first word on the second page has been
2  The other major items included within the proposed
judgment submitted by plaintiffs which were challenged by
defendants in their March 5, 2014 letter, were addressed vis-a-
vis the subject matter involved in this Court's Memorandum &
Order dated April 2, 2014 as amended on April 7, 2014.
-9-

corrected to read "were" and the "a" immediately before the word
"previous" has been deleted.3  
Proposed Book and Bail Draft Notice (Exhibit 1) 
Defendants' comments about the proposed Book and Bail
draft notice read in pertinent part:
   In the third bullet point under Summary,
defendants object to the insertion of the
term "to the best of your recollection." 
Notwithstanding discussions held two years
ago on the proposed notice language, over the
past six months this Court and the parties
have spent considerable time discussing the
contents of the notices.  At no time did
Plaintiff mention that these issues had been
definitely determined in 2012.  It was,
however, agreed and determined during the
recent conferences that the subjects of the
Book and Bail notice and claim form would be
required to attest under the penalty of
perjury to the fact that they were strip
searched upon admission to the NCCC. 
Insertion of the phrase "to the best of your
recollection" is too ambiguous and invites
deception.  These individuals either were or
were not strip searched upon admission to the
Correctional facility.
   Defendants [also] object to the legal
advice provided in the fourth bullet point,
specifically the statement notifying
plaintiffs of the estoppel effect of the
liability concession. 
 
(Defs.' Mar, 5, 2014 Letter at 4.)
The Court is underwhelmed by the objection to "the best
of your recollection" verbiage.  In this Court's January 25, 2012
Order, it addressed the subject now under discussion thusly: 
3  This change has also been made to page 1 of Exhibit 1. 
-10-

   The Court further proposes that those
members of the class who have been identified
as potential "book and bails" should be sent
the B&B Class Notice and a claim form in the
format submitted by plaintiffs, with . . .
the following modifications: In Section 3,
which is entitled "Certification and
Signature," the sentence reading "By signing
this form, I am confirming that the above
information is correct" should be deleted and
replaced with the following language: "I
declare under penalty of perjury that, to the
best of my recollection, I was strip searched
at the Nassau County Correctional Center
following my arrest for a misdemeanor or non-
criminal offense on the dates listed in
Section 2, above."  That sentence shall be
followed with: "I acknowledge that Nassau
County may challenge my claim." 
   Any objections to or comments regarding
the proposals outlined above or the attached
documents shall be filed on or before
February 3, 2012.  Any replies shall be filed
on or before February 10, 2012.
(Jan. 25, 2012 Order at 4.) 
By letter dated February 3, 2012, defendants advised
that they had "no objections to the Notice and Claim Forms
proposed by the Court for . . . the potential Book & Bails." 
(Defs.' Feb. 3, 2012 Letter at 1.)
Based on the County's representation, I viewed โ and
still view โ the matter as resolved.  Incidentally, however,
deletion of the subject modifier to the attestation clause would
likely have an unnecessary inhibiting affect upon aggrieved
persons.  Simply put, some members may be understandably hesitant
to unequivocally swear under penalty of perjury to being strip
-11-

searched upon admission to the NCCC during the class period if,
for instance, their experience was a decade or so ago and this
was not their sole strip search experience.  To the extent their
attestation "to the best of [their] recollection," is arguably
"equivocal," the County is hard pressed to legitimately complain
since (1) it provided the list of class members from its records,
only later carving-out possible book and bail exceptions to that
list, and (2) more importantly, it has the right to challenge the
accuracy of any book and bail attestation.
With respect to defendants' objection to the fourth
bullet point concerning purported "legal advice" being provided
in the Notice, that issue was addressed earlier in reviewing
defendants' challenges to the Non-Book and Bail Draft Notice.
Proposed Non-Book and Bail Claim Form (Exhibit 4)
Defendants advise that "[t]his form is acceptable
subject to the objections [raised and decided] on the record." 
(Defs.' Mar. 5, 2014 Letter at 4.)
Proposed Book and Bail Claim Form (Exhibit 2)
What I said earlier about defendants' objection to the
phrase "to the best of my recollection" is hereby incorporated by
reference.4   
4  Parenthetically, the likely inhibiting affect of deleting
the subject language from this claim form is even more pronounced
since here the class member attests to having been strip searched
on a given day or days instead of sometime during the
approximately three year class period.  
-12-

Defendants' request that the Court add the term "upon
admission" in the second line of "Section 3" is granted.  The
term shall appear in the modified claim form immediately after
the word "searched."
The Court has also changed some of the language in
Section 2 sua sponte.  In the proposed Book and Bail claim form,
that Section reads: "Below are listed the booking dates for each
date of arrest for a misdemeanor or non-criminal offense from May
20, 1996 through June 1, 1999 when you were strip-searched at the
Nassau County Correctional Center."  (Emphasis added).  Telling
the recipients of the form that they "were strip-searched" on the
dates listed runs counter to the very reason that some of the
17,000 believed class members were sent Book and Bail notices and
claims forms, i.e. to determine which of those individual-
arrestees were not strip-searched because they were released on
bail prior to that part of the intake process being conducted. 
Accordingly, Section 2 will be modified by replacing the word
"were" with the term "may have been."  In addition, the box
entitled "Value of Your Claim" under Section 2 has been deleted
as confusing for essentially the same reason, as well as
unnecessary.
Section 3 has also been modified, sua sponte, by
inserting "one or more of" in the second sentence immediately
before the phrase "on the date(s) listed in Section 2," coupled
-13-

with a direction in Section 2 to "cross-out (by putting a line
through) any 'Line #(s)' which pertain to an arrest which did not
result in your being strip searched upon admission to the Nassau
County Correctional Center."  The reason for this modification is
that arrestees within the Book and Bail category who had more
than one qualifying arrest did not necessarily have the same
experience on each occasion.  
CONCLUSION
This Memorandum and Order has been written solely to
explain to counsel the reasons behind the major modifications to
the proposed forms presented by plaintiffs pursuant to my
direction.
SO ORDERED.
Dated: April 11, 2014
       Central Islip, New York 
_________________________
DENIS R. HURLEY, U.S.D.J.
     
    
-14-

Case 0:99-cv-03126-DRH  Document 54-3 
DENIS R. HURLEY, U.S.DJ.: 
In accordance with the August 24,2006 Decision and Order of the Court of Appeals for 
the Second Circuit, and in light of defendants' concession of liability to all class members: 
IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that class certification is granted for liability purposes, and a 
class is hereby certified of all persons arrested for misdemeanors or non-criminal offenses in 
Nassau County who thereafter were strip searched at the Nassau County Correctional Center 
pursuant to defendants' blanket policy, practice and custom which required that all arrestees be 
strip-searched upon admission to the facility, from May 20, 1996 until and including June I, 
1999; and 
IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Beldock Levine & Hoffman LLP is appointed as lead 
class counsel and Emery Celli Brinckerhoff & Abady LLP and Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman 
& Herz LLP as co-class counsel; and 
IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that summary judgment on liability for all strip searches 
upon admission to the facility is granted against defendants Joseph Jablonsky and the County of 
Nassau and in favor of the certified class and each and every member thereof; and 
IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that defendants are directed to disclose to plaintiffs' 
counsel by January 15,2006 the following categories ofinforrnation for each and every member 
of the class from May 20, 1996 until and including June I, 1999: (I) name, (2) last known 
address and all addresses available since the beginning of the class period (with corresponding 
year in which address was provided), (3) phone number, (4) date of birth, (5) social security 
number, (6) gender/sex, (7) marital status, (8) veteran/military status, (9) New York State 
Identification (NYSID) number, (10) Federal Bureau ofInvestigation number, and (II) other 
names or aliases used.  This production is without prejudice to production of further information

documents.text:
Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 1 of 21
FILED 
IN CLERK'S OFFICE 
US DI~TRICTCOURTE.D NY 
I  UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS  *  DEC  1 ยท 2006  * 
2  FOR THE SECOND CIRCUIT 
3 
LONG ISLAND OFFICE 
4 
5  August Term, 2005  cV-99- 2o't~{J)MJ) 
6 
7  (Argued: June 12, 2006  Decided: August 24, 2006) 
8 
9  Docket Nos. 05-4206-cv(L); 05-4211-cv(CON); 05-4242-cv(CON) 
10 
II 
12  IN RE: NASSAU COUNTY STRIP SEARCH CASES 
13 
14 
15 
16  GARDY AUGUSTIN, HEIDI KANE, MARY KATHERINE PUGLIESE, GREGG WILLS, STEVEN ROTH, 
17  OSCAR AVELAR, RALPH DILIELLO, JOHN lAFFALDANO, ON BEHALF OF HIMSELF AND OTHERS 
18  SIMILARLY SITUATED, FRANCIS O'DAY, AND STUART MOSKOWITZ, 
19  Plaintijft-Appellants, 
20  -v.-
21  JOSEPH P. JABLONSKY, SHERIFF OF NASSAU COUNTY, COUNTY OF NASSAU, THOMAS S. 
22  GULOTTA, NASSAU COUNTY EXECUTNE, NASSAU COUNTY SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT, DIVISION 
23  OF CORRECTIONS, PORT WASHINGTON POLICE DISTRICT AND WILLIAM KlLFOIL, CHIEF Of 
24  POLICE, PORT WASHINGTON POLICE DEPARTMENT, JANE/JOHN DoES 1-200, 
25  Defendants-Appellees. 
26 
27  Before: 
28  CABRANES, STRAUB, AND HALL, Circuit Judges. 
29 
30  Appeal from a series of orders of the United States District Court for the Eastern District 
31  of New York (Denis R. Hurley, Judge), denying plaintiffs' repeated class certification motions 
32  for lack of common issue predominance.  The District Court expressed "considerable doubt" as 
33  to whether it could certify a class on the issue of liability pursuant to Rule 23(c)(4)(A) when it 
34  already had determined that plaintiffs' claints as a whole failed to satisfy Rule 23(b)(3)'s 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 2 of 21
1  predominance requirement.  The District Court further concluded that, even if it could do so, 
2  common liability issues that defendants had conceded no longer factored into the predominance 
3  analysis.  The District Court thus denied plaintiffs' motion to certifY a class on the issue of 
4  liability. 
5  We hold that (I) district courts may certifY a class on a particular issue regardless of 
6  whether plaintiffs' claims, as a whole, satisfY the predominance test; (2) the District Court erred 
7  when it excised common liability issues from it.~ predominance analysis due to defendants' 
8  concession; and, as a result, (3) the District Court exceeded its allowable discretion in declining 
9  to certifY a class on the issue ofliability pursuant to Rules 23(b)(3) and (c)(4)(A). 
10  REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED IN PART. 
ll 
12  ROBERT L. HERBST, Beldock Levine & Hoffman LLP (Vera M. Scanlon, Spencer B. 
13  Freedman, on the brief), New York, NY ,for Plaintiffs-Appellants. 
14 
15  MATTHEW D. BRINCKERHOFF, Err.ery Celli Brinckerhoff & Abady LLP, New York, 
16  NY ,for Plaintiffs-Appellants. 
17 
18  JEFFREY G. SMITH, WolfHaldensteinAdler Freeman & Herz, LLP, New York, NY, 
19  for Plaintiffs-Appellants. 
20 
21  DENNIS J. SAFFRAN, Deputy County Attorney (Lorna B. Goodman, County Attorney 
22  of Nassau County, David B. Goldin, Deputy County Attorney, on the brief), Mineola, 
23  NY, for Defendants-Appellees. 
24 
25  STRAUB, Circuit Judge: 
26  This appeal is the latest installment in a series of litigations over the Nassau County 
27  Correctional Center's ("NCCC") blanket strip search policy for newly admitted, misdemeanor 
28  detainees ("the policy").  Plaintiffs, who were strip searched pursuant to the policy, appeal from a 
2 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 3 of 21
series of orders entered in the District Court for the Eastern District of New York (Denis J. 
2  Hurley, Judge) denying their repeated motions for class certification on the ground that 
3  individual issues predominated over common ones. See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3) (requiring that 
4  "questions of law or fact common to the members of the class predominate over any questions 
5  affecting only individual members"). 
6  During the course of class certification motion practice, plaintiffs requested that the 
7  District Court certifY a Rule 23(b)(3) class solely on the issue of liability, as permitted by Rule 
8  23(c)(4)(A).  In response, defendants conceded their liability to plaintiffs.  The District Court 
9  denied the motion.  As an initial matter, the District Court expressed serious doubt over whether 
I 0  it could certify a class on the issue of liability since it already had determined that plaintiffs' 
11  claims, as a whole, failed the predominance test.  Even if it could do so, the District Court 
12  reasoned that defendants' concession removed common liability issues from the predominance 
13  analysis.  With common liability issues so excised, the Court concluded that individual liability 
14  issues, such as the application of an affirmative defense, predominated.  The Court thus denied 
15  plaintiffs' motions for class certification on the issue ofliability. 
16  The precise issues on appeal are whether ( 1) a court may certifY a Rule 23(b) (3) class as 
17  to a particular issue when it already has d-etermined that the claim as a whole fails the 
18  predominance test; (2) common issues that are conceded remain part of the predominance 
19  analysis; and (3) the District Court exceeded its allowable discretion by failing to certifY a class 
20  on the issue of liability.  As set fortb mor<! fully below, we hold that (1) a court may employ rule 
21  23(c )(4 )(A) to certifY a class as to an issue regardless of whether the claim as a whole satisfies 
22  the predominance test; (2) the District Court erred when it concluded that defendants' concession 
3 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 4 of 21
eliminated liability issues from the predominance analysis; and (3) the District Court exceeded its 
2  allowable discretion by failing to certify a class on the issue of liability pursuant to Rules 
3  23(b)(3) and (c)(4)(A).  Accordingly, we reverse the District Court's orders dated September 23, 
4  2003 and November 7, 2003 to the extent that they deny certification as to the issue ofliability, 
5  and we remand for proceedings consistent with this opinion. 
6  BACKGROUND 
7  In 1999, the District Court for the Eastern District of New York held that defendants' 
8  blanket policy of strip searching newly admitted, misdemeanor detainees violated clearly 
9  established Fourth Amendment law.  See Shain v. Ellison, 53 F. Supp. 2d 564 (E.D.N.Y. 1999), 
10  a.ff'd,  273 F.3d 56 (2d Cir. 2001).  Although the policy has never been formally enjoined, Shain 
11  v, Ellison, 356 F.3d 211 (2d Cir. 2004) (vacating injunction for lack of standing), defendant~ 
12  assert that following the District Court's 1999 decision, they ceased implementing it. 
13  Shortly after the District Court's 1999 decision, plaintiffs brought three separate actions 
14  in the Eastern District of New York: Augustin v. Jablonsky, No. 99 Civ. 3126, 0 'Day et al. v. 
15  Nassau County SherifFs Department, et al., No. 99 Civ. 2844, and Ja.ffaldano v. County of 
16  Nassau, No. 99 Civ. 4238.  Together, plaintiffs named as defendants Nassau County, Sheriff 
17  Joseph P. Jablonsky, the Sheriffs Department, County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, the 
18  Division of Corrections, the Port Washington Police District and its chief of police, William 
19  Ki!fbil, and up to 200 subordinate John and Jane Doe corrections officers. 
20  Each action alleged that plaintiffs were arrested on misdemeanor charges unrelated to 
21  weapons or drugs and thereafter strip searched, without individualized suspicion, pursuant to the 
22  policy.  Plaintiffs claimed that the strip searches violated 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, the Fourth, Fifth, 
4 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 5 of 21
Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution, and Article 1, section 12 
2  of the New York State Constitution.  They sought compensatory and punitive damages, a 
3  declaration that the policy was unconstitutional, and an injunction barring enforcement of the 
4  policy.  They also sought to maintain each litigation as a class action. 
5  In February of2000, plaintiffs moved to consolidate all three actions and certify a unified 
6  class pursuant to Rule 23(b)(3).'  Plaintiffs defined the class as tollows: "[A]ll persons arrested 
7  for or charged with non-felony offenses who have been admitted to the Nassau County 
8  Correctional Center and strip searched without particularized reasonable suspicion."  In an 
9  opinion and order dated March 8, 200 I, the District Court granted that branch of the motion 
10  seeking consolidation and denied that branch seeking class certification.  See Augustin v. 
11  Jabolonsky, No. 99 Civ. 3126, 2001 WL 770839 (E.D.N.Y. Mar. 8, 2001). 
12  The District Court determined that plaintiffs satisfied the four requirements of 
13  numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy of representation. See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a). 
14  However, it denied certification for Jack of common issue predominance.  The Court recognized 
15  certain common questions, namely, (I) whether defendants maintained a blanket strip search 
16  policy; (2) whether that policy was unconstitutional; and (3) whether some or all defendants may 
17  be held liable.  Nonetheless, it determined that individualized issues predominated, in particular: 
18  ( 1) whether subordinate Jane and John Doe defendants might escape liability in some cases 
19  because, notwithstanding the blanket policy, they had reasonable suspicion to search certain 
20  detainees; (2) the existence of proximate โข:ausation for each alleged injury; and (3) compensatory 
'Because motion practice on the question of class certification continued in various 
iterations for more than four years, we describe only those aspects of the District Court's 
decisions that are relevant to our own. 
5 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 6 of 21
and punitive damages calculations. 
2  The District Court noted the possibility of sua sponte certifying a class solely on the issue 
3  of liability pursuant to Rule 23( c)( 4}(A), which allows for class certification "with respect to 
4  particular issues." It declined to do so because it did not wish to "undertake plaintiffs' burden" 
5  to "craft and submit a proposal," and because, as a legal matter, it perceived "considerable doubt 
6  as to the propriety of using Rule 23(c)(4)(A) in this fashion." In particular, the Court relied on 
7  Castano v. Am. Tobacco Co., 84 F.3d 734 (5th Cir. 1996) for the proposition that courts may not 
8  employ Rule 23(c)(4)(A) to single out tht' issue ofliability for class treatment unless the "cause 
9  of action, as a whole," first satisfies Rule 23(b)(3)'s predominance requirement.  Id. at 745 n.21 
10  (emphasis added by District Court). 
II  Plaintiffs moved for reconsideration.  They first asserted that they would no longer seek 
12  judgment against subordinate Jane and John Doe defendants.  Since that modification would 
13  render the question of liability identical for nearly all class members, plaintiffs next asserted that 
14  the Court should certify a class on the issue ofliability pursuant to Rule 23(c)(4)(A).  They again 
15  defined the class as "all persons arrested for or charged with non-felony offenses who have been 
16  admitted to the [Nassau County Correctional Center] and strip searched without particularized 
17  reasonable suspicion." 
18  In an opinion and order dated May 23, 2001, the Court agreed that plaintiffs' forbearance 
19  of their claims against subordinate defendants "removes the possibility of individualized liability 
20  determinations."  ''To be sure," the Court acknowledged, "the absence of individualized 
21  questions of liability militates in fkvor of partial certification solely on that issue." It 
22  nevertheless denied the motion. 
6 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 7 of 21
l  The District Court again noted its "concern that partial certification might not be 
2  appropriate in the first instance where th(~ cause of action, as a whole, does not satisfY the 
3  predominance requirement of Rule 23(b)(3)." "Even assuming" that Rule 23(c)(4)(A) could be 
4  used in that fashion, the Court detried the motion because plaintiffs' proposed class definition 
5  "would necessitate mini-trials just to determine class membership." In order to detemtine class 
6  membership, the Court believed, each would-be class member would have to show affirmatively 
7  that he was strip searched without particularized reasonable suspicion - a criterion that the 
8  defmition incorporated.  This burden was complicated by the fact that defendants claimed that 
9  they had ceased the blanket strip search policy after the Eastern District's 1999 decision in Shain, 
I 0  and thereafter conducted strip searches only with particularized reasonable suspicion. 
II  In January 2003, plaintiffs renewe:d their motion for class certification as to liability and 
12  offered a new defmition of the class as follows: "[A]II persons arrested for misdemeanors or non-
13  criminal offenses in Nassau County who thereafter were strip-searehed at the NCCC pursuant to 
14  defendants' blanket policy, practice and custom which required that all arrestees be strip-
15  searched upon admission to the facility ...."   (alterations incorporated).  By referring only to the 
16  "blanket policy," this new defmition did not require plaintiffs to show that reasonable suspicion 
17  was absent in each case, and it excluded individuals strip searched after the 1999 Shain decision, 
18  when defendants ceased implementing the policy.  Plaintiffs also reiterated that they withdrew 
19  their claims against individual John and Jane Doe corrections officers. 
20  In response, defendants conceded "the one common issue" that in their view "might be 
21  appropriate for class certification ... namely, whether the NCCC' s strip search policy during the 
22  class period was constitutional."  (alterations incorporated).  Specifically, defendants recognized 
7 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 8 of 21
I  that they "are bound by Shain under the doctrine of collateral estoppel." 
2  The District Court denied the renewed motion.  In an opinion and order dated September 
3  23, 2003, the Court determined that defendants' concession removed all common liability issues 
4  from its predominance analysis.  Accordingly, the only liability issue that remained was an 
5  individual one: whether, notwithstanding the policy, some plaintiffs were searched based upon 
6  "reasonable and contemporaneously held suspicion." "With the liability issue thus 
7  circumscribed," the Court wrote, "certification as to that issue would not serve any purpose." 
8  Interestingly, the Court recognized that the individualized '"reasonable suspicion inquiries' will 
9  be de minimis" for two reasons: because defendants conceded that "such an inquiry will only be 
10  sought regarding a limited number of plaintiffs," and because pursuant to United States v. Colon, 
11  250 F.3d 130, 138 (2d Cir. 2001), reasonable suspicion must be possessed by some law 
12  enforcement officer at the time of the search and may not be retroactively imputed. 
13  Plaintiffs moved again for reconsideration on October 2, 2003.  In an opinion and order 
14  dated November 7, 2003, the District Court adhered to its earlier determinations and also 
15  concluded-for the first time  that for the same reasons informing its predominance analysis, 
16  plaintiffs failed to satisfy another one of Rule 23(b)(3)'s requirements, specifically, that the 
17  proposed class action be "superior to oth<~r available methods for the fair and efficient 
18  adjudication of the controversy." Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3).  In one last effort to "determine if its 
I 9  decision was in some other way improper," the Court examined the policies of efiiciency and 
20  uniformity animating Rule 23, and concluded that they did not favor certification.  The Court 
21  also noted that individual plaintiffs would have little trouble securing counsel to pursue their 
22  claims because their damages likely would be large enough to provide the necessary economic 
8 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 9 of 21
1  incentive, 
2  The parties later reached a settlement in which defendants paid the lump sum of $350,000 
3  to the ten plaintiffs, who agreed to split the funds equally.  Plaintiffs reserved their right to appeal 
4  the District Court's orders denying class certification, which they timely exercised.' 
5  DISCUSSION 
6  I.  Standard ofR  eview 
7  We review the District Court's denial of class certification for abuse of discretion. 
8  Robinson v, Metro-North Commuter R.R. Co., 267 F.3d 147, 16:2 (2d Cir. 2001).  However, we 
9  "review de novo the district court's conclusions of law that informed its decision to deny class 
10  certification." Parker v. Time Warner Entm 't Co., 331 F.3d 13, 18 (2d Cir. 2003) (quotation 
II  marks omitted).  Further, we are "noticeably less deferential when the district court has denied 
12  class status than when it has certified a class." !d. (quotation marks omitted and alterations 
13  incorporated); Robinson, 267 F.3d at 162.  We note that while the application of the incorrect 
14  legal principle often necessitates reversal under the "abuse of discretion" standard, such reversal 
15  need not indicate any "abuse" by the District Court as that word is commonly understood.  See 
16  Zervos v. Verizon NY, Inc., 252 F.3d 163, 168-69 & nn.4-6 (2d Cir. 2001) (distinguishing 
17  among various meanings of "abuse of discretion"). 
18  II.  The Requirements and Purpose ofR  ule 23(b)(3) 
19 
20  In order to achieve class certification pursuant to Rule 23(b)(3), plaintiffs must (l) satisfy 
21  the four requirements of Rule 23(a), which are numerosity, typicality, commonality, and 
2A  lthough these plaintiffs have se:~led their individual claims, they have reserved their 
right, in the event of a class settlement, to "seek or receive additional compensation for attorney's 
fees and [their] time and effort as ... class representative[s)." 
9 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 10 of 21
adequacy of representation; (2) demonstrate that common "questions oflaw or fact" predominate 
2  over "any questions affecting only individual members"; and (3) establish that the class action 
3  mechanism is "superior to other available methods for the fuir and efficient adjudication of the 
4  controversy." Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(bX3). 
5  As a general matter, the "Rule 23(bX  3) predominance inquiry tests whether proposed 
6  classes are sufficiently cohesive to warrant adjudication by represeritation." in re Visa 
7  Check/MasterMoney Antitrust Litig., 280 F.3d 124, 136 (2d Cir. 2001) (quotation marks 
8  omitted).  The Rule "encompasses those cases in which a class action would achieve economies 
9  of time, effort, and expense, and promote' uniformity of decision as to persons similarly situated, 
I 0  without sacrificing procedural fairness or bringing about other undesirable results." Fed. R. Civ. 
II  P. 23(b)(3) adv. comm. n. to 1966 amend. 
12  In light of these purposes, we have set forth that although "a defense may arise and may 
13  affect different class members diffurently, [this occurrence] does not compel a finding that 
14  individual issues predominate over common ones." in re Visa Check, 280 F.3d at !38 (internal 
15  quotation marks omitted).  So "long as a sufficient constellation of common issues binds class 
16  members together, variations in the sources and application of a defense will not automatically 
17  foreclose class certification." id. (quotation marks omitted and alterations incorporated). 
18  III.  The District Court Erred in Failing to CertifY a Class on the Issue ofL iability 
19  Pursuant to Rules 13(b)(3) and (c)(4)(A) 
20  As set forth more fully below, we conclude that the District Court erred by failing to 
21  certify a class on the issue of liability.'  We first conclude that, contrary to the District Court's 
'We reach this conclusion without considering whether the District Court should have 
certified a class as to plaintiffs' entire claims-an issue that, as set forth more fully below, we 
10 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 11 of 21
I  reservations, a court may employ Rule 23(c)(4)(A) to certifY a class on a particular issue even if 
2  the action as a whole does not satisfY Rute 23(b )(3)'s predominance requirement.  Second, we 
3  hold that the District Court committed legal error in concluding that defendants' concession 
4  eliminated common liability issues from Rule 23(b)(3)'s predominance analysis.  Third, this 
5  error caused the District Court to exceed its allowable discretion in concluding that 
6  individualized liability issues predominated over common ones, and that the class action 
7  mechanism is not a superior litigation vehicle under these circumst<mces. 
8  A.  A District Court May Certify a Class as to Specific Issues Regardless of 
9  Whether the Entire Claim Satisfies Rule 13(b)(3) 
10 
II  Whether a court may employ Rule 23(c)(4)(A) to certifY a class as to a specific issue 
12  where the entire claim does not satisfY Rule 23(b)(3)'s predominance requirement is a matter of 
13  first impression in this Circuit.  See Robinson, 267 F.3d at 167 n.l2 (identifYing question as one 
14  of first impression and declining to resolve it). It also is a matter as to which the Circuits have 
15  split. Id. 
16  The Fiflh Circuit has adopted a "strict application" of Rule 23(b)(3)'s predominance 
17  requirement. ld.  Under this view, "[t]he proper interpretation of the interaction between 
18  subdivisions (b)(3) and (c)(4) is that a cause of action, as a whole, must satisfY the predominance 
19  requirement of (b ){3) and that ( c )(4) is a housekeeping rule that allows courts to sever the 
20  common issues for a class trial." Castano v. Am. Tobacco Co., 84 F.3d 734, 745 n.21 (5th Cir. 
21  1996). 
22  The Ninth Circuit holds a different view.  Pursuant to that court's precedent, "(e]ven if 
ask the District Court to revisit in light of our holdings. 
11 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 12 of 21
1  the common questions do not predominate over the individual questions so that class certification 
2  of the entire action is warranted, Rule 23 authorizes the district court in appropriate cases to 
3  isolate the common issues under Rule 23(c)(4)(A) and proceed with class treatment of these 
4  particular issues."  Valentino v. Carter-Wallace, inc., 97 F.3d 1227, 1234 (9th Cir. 19%); cf 
5  Gunnells v. Healthplan Servs .. Inc., 348 F.3d 417, 439 (4th Cir. 2003) (holding that courts may 
6  employ Rule 23(c) to certify a class as to one claim even though all of plaintiffs' claims, taken 
7  together, do not satisfy the predominance requirement). 
8  We agree with the Ninth Circuit's view of the matter.  First, the plain language and 
9  structure of Rule 23 support the Ninth Circuit's view.  Rule 23(c)(4) provides as follows: 
10  When appropriate (A) an action maybe brought or maintained as a 
11  class action with respect to particular issues, or (B) a class may be 
12  divided into subclasses and each subclass treated as a class, and the 
13  provisions of this rule shall then be construed and applied 
14  accordingly. 
15  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(4) (emphases added). 
16  As the rule's plain language and structure establish, a court must frrst identify the issues 
17  potentially appropriate for certification "and ... then" apply the other provisions of the rule, i.e., 
18  subsection (b)(3) and its predominance analysis.  See Gunnells, 348 F.3d at 439 (reasoning that 
19  the rule's language provides this "express command" that "courts have no discretion to ignore"). 
20  Second, the Advisory Committee Notes confirm this understanding.  With respect to 
21  subsection (c)(4), the notes set forth that, "[f]or example, in a fraud or similar case the action 
22  may retain its 'class' character only through the adjudication ofliability to the class; the members 
23  of the class may thereafter be required to come in individually and prove the amounts of their 
24  respective claims." Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c){4) adv. comm. n. to 1966 amend. (emphasis added). 
12 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 13 of 21
As the notes point out, a court may employ Rule 23(c)(4) when it is the "only'' way that a 
2  litigation retains its class character, i.e., when common questions predominate only as to the 
3  "particular issues" of which the provision speaks.  Further, the notes illustrate that a court may 
4  properly employ this technique to separate the issue of liability from damages. 
5  In addition, as the Fourth Circuit has noted, the Fifth Circuit's view renders subsection 
6  (c)(4) virtually null, which contravenes the "well-settled" principle "that courts should avoid 
7  statutory interpretations that render provisions superfluous." State St. Bank & Trust Co. v. 
8  Salovaara, 326 F.3d 130, 139 (2d Cir. 2003).  Pursuant to the Fifth Circuit's view, "a court 
9  considering the manageability of a class action-a requirement fur predominance under Rule 
10  23(b )(3)(D)- [would have) to pretend that subsection (c)(4 ) - a provision specifically included 
II  to make a class action more manageable ยท-does not exist until after the manageability 
12  determination [has been] made."  Gunnells, 348 F.3d at 439.  Accordingly, "a court could only 
13  use subsection (c)(4) to manage cases that the court had already determined would be 
14  manageable without consideration of subsection (c)(4 )." I d. 
15  Finally, we note that the commentators agree that courts may use subsection (c)(4) to 
16  single out issues for class treatment when the action as a whole does not satisfy Rule 23(b)(3). 
17  See 7A  A Wright & Miller, Federal Practice & Procedure ยง 1790 (3d ed. 2005) (stating that 
18  subsection (c)(4) "best may be used to designate appropriate classes or class issues at the 
19  certification stage" so that "the court can determine whether, as so designated, the other Rule 23 
20  requirements are satisfied"); 6 Alba Conte & Herbert B. Newberg, Newberg on Class Actions ยง 
21  18:7 (4th ed. 2002) ("Even cases which might not satisfy the predominance test when the case is 
22  viewed as a whole may sometimes be certified as a class limited to selected issues that are 
13 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 14 of 21
I  common, under the authority ofRule 23(c)(4)."). 
2  For those reasons, we hold that a court may employ subsection (c)(4) to certify a class as 
3  to liability regardless of whether the claim as a whole satisfies Rule 23(b)(3)'s predominance 
4  requirement. 
5  B.  The District Court Erred When It Concluded that Defendants' Concession 
6  Eliminates Common Liability Issues from Rule 23(b)(3) 's Predominance 
7  Analysis 
8 
9  As noted above, the District Court reasoned that the major liability issues common to the 
I 0  class - whether defendants implemented a blanket strip search policy, and if so, whether they are 
11  liable for it -were eliminated from the predominance analysis by defendants' concession. 
12  Whether a concession can limit the predominance analysis in that fashion also is a question of 
13  first impression.  For three reasons, we conclude that a concession does not eliminate a common 
14  issue from the predominance calculus, and that the District Court erred in holding otherwise. 
15  First, because the predominance analysis tests whether the class is a '"sufficiently 
16  cohesive"' unit, In re Visa Check, 280 F.3d at 136, all factual or legal issues that are common to 
17  the class inform the analysis.  See Amchem Prods., Inc. v.  Windsor, 521 U.S. 591, 621 (1997) 
18  ("Subdivisions (a) and (b) focus court attโข~ntion on whether a pmposed class has sufficient unity 
19  so that absent members can fairly be bmmd by decisions of class representatives.").  In tum, an 
20  issue is common to the class when it is susceptible to generalized, class-wide proof. In re Visa 
21  Check, 280 F.3d at 136 ("In order to meet the predominance requirement ... a plaintiff must 
22  establish that the issues in the class action that are subject to generalized proof, and thus 
23  applicable to the class as a whole, predominate over those issues that are subject only to 
14 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 15 of 21
individualized proof." (internal quotation marks omitted and alteration incorporated)); see also 
2  Heerwagen v. Clear Channel Commc'ns, 435 F.3d 219, 226 (2d Cir. 2006) (noting that "a 
3  plaintiff must show that those issues ... subject to generalized proof outweigh those issues that 
4  are subject to individualized proof); Moore v. Paine Webber, Inc., 306 F.3d 1247, 1252 (2d Cir. 
5  2002) (same).  That the class-wide proof comes in the form of a simple concession rather than 
6  contested evidence certainly shortens the time that the court must spend adjudicating the issue, 
7  but it does nothing to alter the fundamental cohesion of the proposed class, which is the central 
8  concern of the predominance requirement.  See 2 Alba Conte & Herbert B. Newberg, Newberg 
9  on Class Actions ยง 4:25 (4th ed. 2002) {"[T]he predominance test does not involve a comparison 
10  of court time needed to adjudicate common issues weighed against time needed to dispose of 
11  individual issues ...." ); 7AA Wright & Miller, Federal Practice and Procedureยง 1778 (3d ed. 
12  2005) ("[C]lockwatching is not very helpful in ascertaining whether class-action treatment would 
13  be desirable in a particular case.").  Similarly, the fact that an issue is conceded or otherwise 
14  resolved does not mean that it ceases to be an "issue" for the purposes of predominance analysis. 
15  Even resolved questions continue to implicate the "common nucleus of operative facts and 
16  issues" with which the predominance inquiry is concerned. See Waste Mgmt. Holdings, Inc. v. 
17  Mowbray, 208 F.3d 288, 299 (1st Cir. 2000) ("[T]he fact that an issue has been resolved on 
18  summary judgment does not remove it from the predominance calculus.").  Just as much as do 
19  contested issues, resolved issues bear on the key question that the analysis seeks to answer: 
20  whether the class is a legally coherent unit of representation by which absent class members may 
21  fair! y be bound. 
22  Second, Rule 23 seeks greater efficiency via collective adjudication and, relatedly, greater 
15 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 16 of 21
uniformity of decision as to similarly situated parties.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3) adv. comm. n. 
2  to 1966 amend.  For these reasons we have written that when plaintiffs are "allegedly aggrieved 
3  by a single policy of defendants," such as the blanket policy at issue here, the case presents 
4  "precisely the type of situation for which the class action devioe is suited" since many nearly 
5  identical litigations can be adjudicated in unison. In re Visa Check, 280 F.3d at 146. 
6  Eliminating conceded issues from Rule 23(bX  3)' s predominance calculus would 
7  undermine the goal of efficiency by requiring plaintiffs who share a "commonality of the 
8  violation and the harm," nonetheless to pursue separate and potentially numerous actions 
9  because, ironically, liability is so clear. ld. (noting that class action management "problems pale 
I 0  in comparison to the burden on the courts that would result from trying the cases individually"). 
11  Such a result also undermines the goal of uniformity by creating the risk of inconsistent decisions 
12  through the repeated litigation of the same question; here, for example, each individual plaintiff 
13  would have to establish anew that defendants were collaterally estopped by their prior concession 
14  and, if not, that defendants were liable on the merits.  Cf Waste Mgmt. Holdings, Inc., 208 F.3d 
15  at 299 (concluding that because certification was "necessary to determine whether the prior 
16  resolution carries res judicata effect with respect to purported class members," the district court 
17  properly took account of"the common nucleus of operative facts and issues, even though certain 
18  of these already had been resolved").  Although defendants have conceded liability to these 
19  plaintiffs, there is no guarantee that they would concede liability in a ease or series of cases 
20  involving significantly higher damages.  Further, courts might differ as to whether, in light of the 
21  settlement, the requirements of collateral estoppel were met, specifically, whether the issue of 
22  liability was "actually litigated and decided" and whether its "resolution ... was necessary to 
16 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 17 of 21
support a valid and final judgment on the merits." Ball v. A.O. Smiih Corp., 451 F.3d 66, 69 (2d 
2  Cir. 2006); cf In re Tamoxifen Citrate Antitrust Litig., 429 F.3d 370, 387 n.15 (2d Cir. 2005) 
3  ("[I)t is clearly a permissible byproduct of settlement that future hypothetical plaintiffs might be 
4  forced to relitigate the same issues involved in the settled cases."); Marvel Characters, Inc. v. 
5  Simon, 310 F.3d 280,289 (2d Cir. 2002). 
6  Finally, we find further support for our view in the specific circumstances of this case. 
7  Defendants possess, but have not disclosed, records of all the newly-admitted misdemeanor 
8  detainees strip searched pursuant to the blanket policy.  Absent class certification and its 
9  attendant class-wide notice procedures, most of these individuals - who potentially number in the 
10  thousands -likely never will know that defendants violated their clearly established 
II  constitutional rights, and thus never will he able to vindicate those rights.  As a prnctical matter, 
12  then, without use of the class action mechanism, individuals harmed by defendants' policy and 
13  practice may lack an effective remedy altogether.  Cf Deposit Guar. Nat. Bank v. Roper, 445 
14  U.S. 326, 339 (1980) (noting that in certain cases "aggrieved persons may be without any 
15  effective redress unless they may employ the class-action device''); Tardiff v. Knox County, 365 
16  F.3d I, 7 (I st Cir. 2004) ("[F]or most strip search claimants, class status here is not only the 
17  superior means, but probably the only feasible one (one-way collateral estoppel aside), to 
18  establish liability and perhaps damages.").  Further, if defendants may utilize their concession to 
19  defeat class certification, it would work the perverse result of allowing them to escape the cost of 
20  their unconstitutional behavior precisely because their liability is too plain to be denied.  No 
21  other court has sanctioned such a result; nor shall we. 
22  Accordingly, we hold that defendants' concession of liability does not eliminate that 
17 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 18 of 21
otherwise common issue from Rule 23(b)(3)'s predominance analysis, and the District Court 
2  erred when it concluded to the contrary. 
c. 
3  The District Court Erred in Determining that, as to Liability, Individual Issues 
4  Predominated 
5 
6  As we have established, the District Court was ( 1) free to certify a class on the issue of 
7  liability notwithstanding its conclusion that the action as a whole did not satisfy the 
8  predominance requirement and (2) required to consider conceded common liability issues in its 
9  predominance analysis.  We now apply these principles to the District Court's opinion and order 
I 0  dated September 23, 2003 in which it derJed certification on the issue of liability, as well as that 
II  dated November 7, 2003 in which it adhered to its September decisinn.  The class definition at 
12  issue was as follows: "[A]ll persons arrested for misdemeanors or non-criminal offunses in 
13  Nassau County who thereafter were strip-searched at the NCCC pursuant to defendants' blanket 
14  policy, practice and custom which requin:d that all artestees be strip-searched upon admission to 
15  the facility ...."   (alterations incorporated). 
16  As noted, that definition obviated the need for individualized proceedings to determine 
17  class membership.  The definition referenced only defendants' "blanket policy," thus avoiding 
18  questions of probable cause and excluding individuals strip searched after the policy's cessation. 
19  Since defendants possess records of misdemeanor detainees strip searched during the policy 
20  period, determining class membership would be simple. In re Visa Check, 280 F.3d at 142 
21  (approving class certification where "class members ... can be identified by defendants' own 
22  records"}. 
23  The class definition also implicated two broad common liability issues: whether the 
18 

Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 19 of 21
blanket policy existed and whether defendants are liable for its implementation.  The only 
2  countervailing, individualized liability issue was whether, regardless of the policy, some 
3  plaintiffs were strip searched based upon "reasonable and contemporaneously held suspicion." 
4  The existence of this defense does "not ... foreclose class certification." Id. at 138 (internal 
5  quotation marks omitted).  Further, as the District Court recognized, "any such 'reasonable 
6  suspicion inquiries' will be de minimis"; indeed, defendants set forth that "such an inquiry will 
7  only be sought regarding a limited number of plaintiffs."  In light of the pervasive character of 
8  the common liability issues and the admittedly de minimis nature of individualized liability 
9  issues, we conclude that the District Court erred by holding that individual liability issues 
10  predominated over common ones in its decisions dated September 23, 2003, and November 7, 
11  2003. 
12  D.  The District Court Erred in Concluding that the Class Action Device Is Not a 
13  Superior Litigation Mechanism 
14 
15  For Rule 23(b)(3) certification to be proper, a class action also must be the most "fair and 
16  efficient" method of resolving this case.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3).  In analyzing that question, 
17  courts must consider four nonexclusive factors: (I) the interest of the class members in 
18  maintaining separate actions; (2) "the extent and nature of any litigation concerning the 
19  controversy already commenced by or against members of the class"; (3) "the desirability or 
20  undesirability of concentrating the litigation ofthe claims in the particular forum"; and (4) "the 
21  difficulties likely to he encountered in the management of a class action." See Fed. R. Civ. P. 
22  23(b)(3).  Contrary to the District Court's conclusion in its decision dated November 7, 2003, all 
23  of these factors -as well as the reasons set forth above regarding efficiency and fairness - favor 
19 

โข  Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 20 of 21
I  class certification. 
2  First, the class members have little interest in maintaining separate actions since there 
3  already exists a concession of liability in this action and, without class notification, most putative 
4  class members will not even know that they suffered a violation of their constitutional rights. 
S  Second, this action already has progress<~d substantially and, again, offers the benefit of a liability 
6  phase that can be resolved quickly and conclusively. Third, concentrating the litigation in one 
7  forum simplifies and streamlines the litigation process.  Fourth, we perceive little difficulty in 
8  managing a class action on the issue of liability, especially since the District Court already has 
9  noted that any individualized inquiries will be few and fur between.  Accordingly, we conclude 
10  that the District Court erred in holding that a class action was not the most fair and efficient 
1 I  litigation vehicle under these circumstances. 
12  CONCLUSION 
13  We hold that (1) district courts may employ Rule 23(c)(4)(A) to certify a class on a 
14  designated issue regardless of whether the claim as a whole satisfies the predominance test; (2) 
15  conceded common issues remain part of the predominance analysis; and (3) the District Court 
16  exceeded its allowable discretion in denying Rule 23(b)(3) and (c)(4)(A) class certification on the 
17  issue ofliability in its decisions dated September 23, 2003 and November 7, 2003.' 
4Because we have found that certification as to liability is proper pursuant to Rnle 
23(b) (3), there is "no necessity" of addressing alternate grounds for certification, such as Rule 
23(b)(2), that the District Court rejected.  Cf. In re VIsa Check, 280 F.3d at 147 (declining to 
review district court's ruling on Rule 23(b)(2) certification after concluding that Rule 23(b)(3) 
certification was proper) (internal quotation marks omitted).  Further, since we base our decision 
on the September 23, 2003 and November 7, 2003 orders, we need not consider the District 
Court's August 20, 2004 order, in which it rejected a radically different class definition for 
failure to satisfy Rule 23(a). 
20 

โข 
Case 0:99-cv-02844-DRH     Document 119-2      Filed 10/10/2006     Page 21 of 21
In light of our direction to certifY a class on the issue of liability pursuant to the definition 
2  set forth in the September 23 decision, we also instruct the District Court to consider anew 
3  whether to certifY a class as to damages as well.  The District Court should bear in mind that 
4  "[t]here are a number of management tools available to a district court to address any 
5  individualized damages issues," such as bifurcation, the use of a magistrate or special master, 
6  alteration of the class definition, the creation of subclasses, or even decertification after a finding 
7  of liability.  In re Visa Check, 280 F.3d at 141. 
8  In sum, we remand to the District Court with instructions to certifY a class as to liability 
9  and consider certifYing a damages class as well. 
21

UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS 
FOR THE  
SECOND CIRCUIT
 
 
 
  At a Stated Term of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, held at the 
Thurgood Marshall United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, in the City of New York, on the 
18th day of August, two thousand and sixteen. 
 
Before:  Josรฉ A. Cabranes, 
Rosemary S. Pooler, 
Denny Chin,  
      Circuit Judges. 
__________________________________________________ 
   
In re NASSAU COUNTY STRIP SEARCH CASES   
  ORDER 
Gardy Augustin, Heidi Kane, Mary Katherine Pugliese, Gregg   
Wills, Steven Roth, Oscar Avelar, Ralph Diliello, John  Docket Nos. 14-1388(L),            
Iaffaldano, Francis O'Day and Stuart Moskowitz, on behalf of                       14-1437(XAP)  
themselves and others similarly situated, 
 
                     Plaintiffs - Appellees - Cross-Appellants, 
 
v. 
 
Nassau County Sheriff's Department, Division of Correction, 
Nassau County, Joseph Jablonsky, Nassau County Sheriff,  
 
                     Defendants - Appellants - Cross-Appellees. 
__________________________________________________ 
 
 
  Defendants-Appellants-Cross-Appellees filed a motion to recall and stay the mandate 
pending the filing of a petition for writ of certiorari in the Supreme Court.  Plaintiffs-Appellees- 
Cross-Appellants opposed the motion. 
 
  IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that the motion is DENIED. 
 
 
              For the Court: 
 
              Catherine OโHagan Wolfe, 
                                  Clerk of Court

THOMAS R. SUOZZI                                                      LORNA B. GOODMAN

COUNTY OF NASSAU

Ralph G. Caso Executive and Legislative Building

Mineola, New York 11501-4820 
516-571-3056

June 24, 2005 
Honorable Denis R. Hurley 
United States District Court

100 Federal Plaza 
Central Islip, New York 11722 
     
    Re:    In re Nassau County Strip Search Cases 
              99-cv-2844 (DRH) (ARL) (Master Case) 
 
Dear Judge Hurley: 
 
This office represents the defendants in the above-referenced action.  A settlement was reached in 
this matter on January 5, 2005 following a conference and the terms were placed on the record that day 
before your Honor.  The settlement was, however, contingent upon approval by the Nassau County 
Legislature.  Such approval was obtained on June 9, 2005, and the various necessary steps have 
commenced for the funds to be raised through sale of a bond.   
Today I am electronically filing the Stipulation of Settlement.  It has separate signature pages for 
each attorney.  Attached to this letter is a proposed Final Judgment which has been approved by all 
parties for your Honorโs consideration and endorsement.  
 
              Respectfully, 
 
 
                                                         Bernadette K. Ford (4339)       
                 Deputy County Attorney

Matthew D. Brinckerhoff, Esq. 
Jeffrey G. Smith, Esq.

documents.text:
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
EASTERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK
-------------------------------X
   MEMORANDUM AND ORDER
In re NASSAU COUNTY STRIP                99-CV-2844(DRH)
SEARCH CASES  
-------------------------------X
A P P E A R A N C E S:
For Plaintiffs:
Giskan Solotaroff Anderson & Stewart LLP
11 Broadway Suite 2150
New York, New York 10004
  By: Robert L. Herbst, Esq.
 Oren Giskan, Esq.
Beldock Levine & Hoffman LLP
99 Park Avenue, Suite 1600
New York, New York 10016
  By: Vera M. Scanlon, Esq.
Emery Celli Brinckerhoff & Abady LLP
75 Rockefeller Plaza, 20th Floor
New York, New York 10019
  By: Matthew D. Brinckerhoff, Esq.
 Mariann Wang, Esq.
Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz, LLP
270 Madison Avenue
New York, New York 10016
  By: Jeffrey G. Smith, Esq.
 Martin Restituyo, Esq.
For Defendants:
John Ciampoli
Nassau County Attorney
One West Street
Mineola, New York 11501
  By: Dennis J. Saffran, Esq.
           Liora Ben-Sorek, Esq.     
HURLEY, Senior District Judge
The captioned case, a class action,1 was tried before
1  The class definition is โall persons arrested for
misdemeanors or non-criminal offenses in Nassau County who

me, non-jury, on the issue of general damages sustained by
class members as a result of being unconstitutionally2 strip
searched at the Nassau County Correctional Center (โNCCCโ)
following their arrests for non-criminal offenses and/or
misdemeanors.
  The purpose of this decision is to provide my
Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law pursuant to Fed. R.
Civ. P. 52.
BACKGROUND
After extensive pretrial motion practice, including
numerous unsuccessful efforts to achieve class certification,
plaintiffs, proffering a reconfigured proposed class
definition, requested certification pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P.
23(b)(3) or, in the alternative, for partial certification as
thereafter were strip searched at the Nassau County Correctional
Center pursuant to defendantsโ blanket policy, practice and
custom which required that all arrestees be strip-searched upon
admission to the facility, from May 20, 1996 until and including
June 1, 1999.โ  (Jan. 16, 2007 Order at 2.) 
2  In 1999, the Hon. Leonard D. Wexler of the Eastern
District of New York held that Nassau Countyโs blanket policy of
strip searching all newly admitted misdemeanor and non-criminal
charged detainees at the NCCC violated clearly established Fourth
Amendment law.  Shain v. Ellison, 53 F. Supp. 2d 564 (E.D.N.Y.
1999), affโd in part and remanded in part, 273 F.3d 56 (2d Cir.
2001).  Following Judge Wexlerโs 1999 decision, Nassau County
reported that it โhad officially ended its blanket strip search
policy.โ  Shain v. Ellison, 356 F.3d 211, 214 (2d Cir. 2004). 
And, as explained in the text, infra, defendants in the present
case have conceded liability as to subject strip searches leaving
solely the issue of damages to be resolved.  
-2-

to liability pursuant to then Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(4)(A). 
Defendants countered by conceding liability, acknowledging that
the strip searches of the class members for non-felony offenses
were conducted โ with a few possible exceptions which were
never pursued โ absent reasonable suspicion to believe that
such arrestees had contraband on their persons upon admissions
to the NCCC.
   Based on defendantsโ concession, I deleted the
liability issue from the certification analysis and found that
the damages sustained by the various class members required
individual analysis, i.e. did not lend themselves to class
treatment.  My resulting orders denying the requested relief,
as well as reconsideration of that denial โ dated September 23,
2003 and November 7, 2003 โ were appealed by plaintiffs to the
Second Circuit Court of Appeals.  The Circuit, by decision
dated August 24, 2006, reversed those orders โto the extent
they denied certification as to the issue of liability,โ In re
Nassau County Strip Search Cases, 461 F.3d 219, 222 (2d Cir.
2006), and directed me โto certify a class on the issue of
liability pursuant to the definition set forth in the September
23 decision . . . [and] consider anew whether to certify a
class as to damages as well.โ  Id. at 231.  Accordingly, I
certified a class as to liability as directed, and also sought
input from counsel concerning the damages certification issue. 
-3-

As a result of that process, the Court, as detailed in its
March 27, 2008 Memorandum and Order, reported at 2008 WL
850268, concluded that the general damages sustained by each
class member attributable to the affront to human dignity
necessarily entailed in being illegally strip searched
satisfied the predominance requirement of Fed. R. Civ. P.
23(b)(3) and thus extended class certification to include
damages.   
A jury trial was scheduled to begin on November 30,
2009 on the issue of general damages with the special injuries
sustained by individual class members to be resolved in a
subsequent damages phase or phases of the proceeding.  On
November 26, 2009, counsel for plaintiffs and defendants
contacted chambers indicating that their respective clients
waived the right to a jury trial to the extent of placing the
general damages determination in my hands.  The trial was held
on November 30, December 1, 2, 3, 7, 8, 9, 10, 14, 15, and 16,
2009, with counselsโ post-trial submissions being finalized via
the filing of Defendantsโ Amended Reply to Plaintiffsโ Proposed
Findings of Fact on April 23, 2010.
Evidence at trial was presented in various forms
including the testimony of multiple class members describing 
the strip searches to which they were subjected upon admission
to NCCC, and of numerous correction officers detailing their 
-4-

procedures in conducting, cumulatively thousands of such
searches during the class period, with the goal being to
provide me with an understanding of the steps involved in the
process as well as the surrounding circumstances.
Initially my Findings of Fact will be provided,
followed by Conclusions of Law including the general damages
awarded per strip search.
FINDINGS OF FACT
1. Each class member was stripped searched by
a correction officer (โCOโ) upon admission to NCCC following an
arrest for a misdemeanor or non-criminal offense absent
reasonable suspicion to believe that he or she harbored
contraband;3 some class members, due to more than one such
admission, were strip searched on more than one occasion. 
2. All strip searches of new admittees took
place in the operations area on the first floor of the D
Building at the NCCC in either the Male Clothing Room (โMCRโ)
3  All class members were necessarily strip searched given
the definition of the class.  However, the precise size of the
class has not yet been determined.  Although the parties agree
that the non-felony admittees during the class period, and
concomitant searches, total approximately 17,000 and 23,000
respectively, defendants contend that not all such admittees were
strip searched; some, as the result of the practice of โbook and
bail,โ were released from the correctional facility after
admission but prior to a strip search being conducted due to bail
being posted on their behalf in the interim.  (See Trial
Transcript (โTr.โ) 1911:1-1912:4.)  That issue is presently sub
judice.  
-5-

or Female Clothing Room (โFCRโ) depending upon the gender of
the new admittee.  (Tr. at 784:19-25.)
3. It is undisputed that a correction officer
of the same gender as the inmate conducted each search.  
4. The parties agree that about 15% of the
strip searched new admittees were female and 85% male.  (Tr. at
1909:1-1911:9.)
5. There was no written procedure or policy in
effect at the NCCC governing the manner in which strip searches
were to be conducted, nor was the topic a subject of in-house
training.  (See, e.g., Tr. at 943:7-944:19, 951:4-24, 1055:25-
1057:3, 1058:12-15, 1186:6-9, 1187:6-9, 1301:10-12, 1803:11-14,
1873:20-25, 1876:22-25; Pound Dep. Tr. (Court Ex. 4) at 106:19-
107:2.) 
The Court is mindful that in some of the above
cited testimonial references provided in support of these two
factual findings, the CO witnesses โ some of whom conducted
hundreds of strip searches of new admittees during the relevant
time frame (Tr. at 826:22-25, 967:17-19, 1142:11-14) โ did not
recall ever seeing a written document or having received in-
service training on strip searches as distinct from denying
their existence.  However, the pervasiveness of the failure to
recollect such institutional guidance being furnished, viewed
in conjunction with the absence of convincing, countervailing
-6-

evidence causes me to conclude that neither was provided. 
Moreover, managerial oversight as to the manner in which strip
searches were conducted appears to have been nonexistent.  (Id.
at 944:16-25.)  
6. Not only was there an absence of in-service
training, none of the testifying COs recalled receiving
training at the Police Academy on the subject. (See, e.g., Tr.
at 1057:21-25, 1298:15-18, 1649:5-7.)  Some officers believed
they learned the procedure from colleagues (id. at 1058:16-21, 
1624:4-7, 1717:25-1718:3) and, in any event, all testified that
they developed their own procedure over time which was in the
main consistently followed subject to occasional modifications
based primarily on such factors as the age and/or physique of
the subject being searched. (See, e.g., id. at 827:5-12, 938:7-
13 (Cpl. Keith Jorgensen: โEveryone has their own method of
doing itโ); id. at 942:7-25, 1240:11-13, 1414:24-1415:1.)      
7. Not surprisingly, given the absence of a
written procedure or formal training, the manner in which the
strip searches were conducted varied from class member to class
member although there were common core elements.  For example,
class member Mary P.4 described the search to which she was
subjected on February 16, 1998 thusly: she was directed to, and
4  Given the sensitivity of the subject matter, the Court
has elected to refer to testifying class members by their first
names and the first letter of their last names.
-7-

did remove her clothes (Tr. 61:16-62:3), and then, as ordered
by the CO, she โlifted [her] armsโ (id. at 63:8-21), โlifted
and moved her breasts up and then side to sideโ (id. at 64:1),
โr[a]n [her] fingers through [her] hairโ (id. at 64:17-18),
โsquat[ted],โ โcough[ed],โ โwiggled her toes,โ โben[t] over,โ
โcough[ed again],โ and โspread [her buttock] cheeks,โ as well
as โst[u]ck out [her] tongue [and] move[d] it side to side.โ 
(Id. at 64:23-65:6.)  For class member Heidi K., parts of the
search occurred while she was clothed, with the CO beginning
the process by checking her hair (id. at 292:1-10) and visually
examining her opened mouth (id. 292:14-16).  Heidi K. then, as

The answers given by Pound at his deposition are
insufficient to warrant the 1997 Lesson Planโs receipt into
evidence under Fed. R. Evid. 803(6).  That the witness, at
deposition, answered the leading foundational questions asked
by counsel in the affirmative is not dispositive on the issue
of admissibility when the concomitant substantive evidence is
to the contrary.  In such a situation, form is necessarily
trumped by substance lest the purpose of the rules of evidence
be perverted.  See Fed. R. Evid. 102.  Here, Pound prepared one
lesson plan during his multiple years of service.  The mere
fact that the lesson plan was prepared while Pound was in the
Countyโs employ does render his work product a business record. 
The same is true of the predecessor plan upon which Poundโs
-33-

plan was modeled, the origins and use of which stand largely
undeveloped.  The business records exception to the hearsay
rule16 rests on the โregularityโ and the โroutineโ embodied in
the preparation of the record sought to be introduced; the
โrecord must [also] be made contemporaneously with what it
records or reports.โ  4 Fedโl Evidence ยง 8:77 (3d ed.).  Simply
put, a juxtapositioning of the cited portions of the deposition
testimony of Pound and, incidentally, of Sergeant Harrs as
well,17 with the rationale underlying the business records
exception indicates a misfit.  See Seattle-First Natโl Bank v.
Randall, 532 F.2d 1291, 1296 (9th Cir. 1976)(bankโs loan
procedure manual not admissible under the business records
exception to the hearsay rule); Gonzalez v. City of Garden
Grove, 2006 WL 5112757 (C.D.Cal. Dec. 4, 2006) (training
manuals inadmissible hearsay); see also 4 Fedโl Evidence ยง 8:77
(3d Ed.) (โIt seems that Fed. R. Evid. 803(6) does not embrace
operating or procedural manuals . . . .  Such documents simply
do not fit the terms of the exception.  They do not report or
assess particular matters . . . and the contemporaneity

Handbook on Evidence, ยง 801:15.
